byline.original: By STEPHEN LABATON and JEFF ZELENY

docs.lead_paragraph: Will the emergence of a malpractice provision in health care legislation prompt lawyers to pull back on financial contributions to members of Congress? Time will tell, of course. But so far in the 2010 election cycle, lawyers and law firms have given incumbent members of Congress more money than any other industry has given, $13.8 million, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. That surpasses the $8.3 million given by health care professionals, who are ranked No. 2.
docs.abstract: Center for Responsive Politics reports that lawyers and law firms have given incumbent members of Congress $13.8 million so far in 2010, surpassing $8.3 million given by health care professionals; it remains to be seen if emergence of malpractice provision in health care legislation will prompt lawyers to pull back on financial contributions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, said Monday that he would oppose any resolution rebuking Representative Joe Wilson of South Carolina for heckling President Obama during his speech to Congress last Wednesday night. Anticipating that House Democrats would offer a resolution on Tuesday formally admonishing Mr. Wilson for shouting ''You lie!'' at the president, Mr. Boehner accused them of ''petty partisanship.''
docs.abstract: House Republican leader John Boehner says he will oppose any resolution rebuking Rep Joe Wilson for heckling Pres Obama during speech to Congress about health care (S)
docs.snippet: Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, said Monday that he would oppose any resolution rebuking Representative Joe Wilson of South Carolina for heckling President Obama during his speech to Congress last Wednesday night....

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama's embattled health care plan will get full-throated support from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. on Tuesday, although the federation will urge the president to push farther than he may be prepared to go. Delegates to the federation's convention in Pittsburgh are set to approve a resolution that calls for a far-reaching overhaul of the health care system, including a government-run option to compete with private insurers. The president, who will be addressing the convention Tuesday, has said he supports the public option but has also indicated he will not insist on it.
docs.abstract: AFL-CIO plans to urge Pres Obama to push further than he may be prepared to go in overhauling health care system by including public option and requirement that all employers contribute to costs through pay or play system (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A major component of the proposed health care overhaul is an expansion of Medicaid, the state-federal insurance program for the poorest Americans. It is an idea that, philosophically at least, Democrats tend to favor more than Republicans. But in the current debate, Democrats have reason to feel conflicted. Many of the states that have the most stringent Medicaid eligibility rules, and so would get significant extra amounts of federal aid to add people to the rolls, tend to vote Republican, and a large number of them favored John McCain over Barack Obama last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's going to be awfully hard to avoid President Obama on television this Sunday. The president will appear on five Sunday talk shows -- five -- to press his case for changes to the health care system, White House officials said Monday. That is a presidential record.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama is scheduled to appear on five Sunday talk shows on September 20 to press his case for health care reform (S)
